div.head: THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE
No. 7,566] ALEXANDRIA, MONDAY, SEPTEMBER 24, 1906. [SIX PAGES P.T. 1.
The Eastern Telegraph Company, Limited.
div.p:
This Company's system of submarine telegraph
cables is the most direct and quickest means of
communication from Egypt to Europe, North and
South America, East, South and West Africa,
India, Australia, New Zealand, China and Japan.

To secure quick transmission, telegrams should
be marked Via Eastern.

For latest average time to London, see daily
bulletin in this paper.

STATIONS IN EGYPT: Alexandria, Cairo,
Suez, Port-Tewfik, Port-Saïd, Suakin. Head
Office. London.

div.head: KHEDIVIAL MAIL LINE.
div.p: Express Steamers leave Alexandria every Wednesday at 4 p.m. for PIRAEUS, SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE, in connection with Orient Express train-de-luxe for Vienna, Paris, and London.

Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 4 p.m., and Port Said every Sunday at 6 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MESSINA, continuing in alternate weeks to LARNACA and LIMASSOL (Cyprus).

Steamers leave Suez fortnightly on Wednesday at 6 p.m. for PORT SUDAN and SUAKIN direct returning from Suakin every Wednesday noon. Every Mondayat 6 p.m. a steamer leaves SUEZ for JEDDAH continuing every other week to SUAKIN, MASSOWAH, HODEIDSH, ADEN. Intermediate steamers do no proceed beyond JEDDAH but call at TOR, (for SINAI) EL WEDJ and YAMBO as required.
N.B.—Deck chairs provided for the use of passengers, excellent cuisine and table wine free.
Steamer plans may be seen and passages booked at the Company’s Agencies at Alexandria, Cairo, Port Said, and Suez, or at THOS. COOK & SON or other Tourist Agency.

div.p: SUBSCRIPTIONS.—Alexandria, Cairo, and the Interior of Egypt (including delivery in Alexandria or postage to subscriber’s address) P.T. 231½ per annum, P.T. 116 for six months, P.T. 80 for three months. To other countries in the Postal Union P.T. 273 (£2.16s.) per annum. Six months P.T. 136½ (£1.8s.), three months P.T. 92 (£0.19s.) N.B.—Subscriptions commence from the 1st or 16th of any month.

ADVERTISEMENTS.—P.T. 4 per line. Minimum charge P.T. 20. Births, Marriages, or Deaths, not exceeding three lines, P.T. 20. Every additional line P.T. 10. Notices in news column P.T. 20 per line. Contracts entered into for standing advertisements.

div.head: The Egyptian Gazette
The English Daily Newspaper, Established 1830.
Editor and Manager- - R. Smelling
Price: ONE PLASTRE TARIFF.
Monday, September 24, 1906
DANGERS OF PAN-ISLAMISM
div.p: In commenting on an interesting letter from its correspondent in Constantinople, emphasizing the dangers of the Pan-Islamic agitation now going on in North Africa and in Egypt, the “Birmingham Daily Post” remarks that there is need for watchfulness, as is made evident by Lord Cromer’s Reports and by the warning uttered by Sir Deward Grey shortly before the rising of Parliament; but to positive facts time brings us few additions that are worthy of notice. Such as there are seem to be of a favourable rather than of a disquieting nature. After commenting upon the Sultan’s illness and the unwelcome complications which his disease would bring forth, our contemporary continues: -We do not suggest that there is cause for alarm, or even for anxiety- though there may be too much for watchfulness of a kind that can best be exercised through the secret intelligence channels of the Egyptian and Indian Governments. We get little news from Egypt; but this is not one of those cases in which no news is good news. The temper of an alien people is always inscrutable A man who imagines himself to be a judge of character and disciplines his faculties to the estimation of his fellows may grossly deceive himself as to the real aims and qualities of one whom he sees daily. It is impossible to know the workings of the mind of a secretive friend, or even of one who uses candour as a veil. Still less easy is it to tell what is passing in the mind of a people alien in race, in mental constitution, in cast of thought. The English in Egypt have ever been conscious of this difficulty, but, being practical men, with an ingrained racial habit of doing things rather than thinking about what is intangible, they have come to ignore it. The things they have done have been so good, and they have rightly been so well pleased with their own handiwork that they had begun to think that the Egyptians themselves were equally delighted. The Pan-Islamic agitation appears to have shattered that belief. The Egyptian accepts the benefits of English control, but there is no gratitude in him. He is an unchangeable Mahomedan, and would rather be tyrannically ruled by a despot of his own creed than be raised to the pinnacle of posterity on a basis of freedom won for him by an infidel. Hence his heart incline, to Constantinople rather than to the office of Lord Cromer at Cairo. In this is to be found the secret of his peculiar and dangerous susceptibility to an agitation fraught with risk to our ascendancy in Egypt. It is quite intelligible nature can affect surprise at it. If we English have until lately looked upon the Egyptians as beings whose hearts beat with ours, as men who had as much interest in retaining us as we have in remaining in occupation, and as having as much goodwill for us as we have for them, we have but made a characteristic national mistake. We govern other races without understanding them. We are so engrossed in the practical work of governing that we have no time to comprehend the governed. Then something occurs which brings comprehension with a flash, and we find that instead of our good administration having won us loyalty and affection, it has gained us nothing but sullen acquiescence. This is what appears to have happened in Egypt, where sullenness may, at the bidding of the Khalifa at Constantinople, develop into something worse. Indeed, if our correspondent in that capital is, as we believe him to be, a credible witness, the authorities there will do what they can to hasten the development, and not only in Egypt, but also in India.

div.head: Local and General
div.p: Italian Cruiser
The Italian cruiser Vesnvio is now at Port Said undergoing slight repairs. She sails for the Far East tomorrow.
The Plague
Another case of plague was admitted to Alexandria hospital yesterday. Two patients were discharged cured. Today's bulletin is blank.
Colonel Sparkes Bey's Estate
Colonel William Spottiswoode Sparkes (Sparkes Bey)C.M.G, of 5. Pall Mall Place. Pall Mall. S.W . left estate of the value of £27,945, with net personalty £7,490.
Foreign Pilgrim Season
Our Suez correspondent reports that the foreign pilgrim season has started already, and, so far, over 500 pilgrims have left Suez for Jeddah by the Khedivial Mail Line steamers.
Embezzlement in Cairo
On Saturday a native employe of a Cairo Insurance Company. Elias Gubara by name, was arrested by the Cairo Parquet for disposing of L.E. 400, which he had collected from the Company’s clients.
No Plague at Djeddah

Nouri Bey. Secretary to Gbazi Mukbtar Pashs, High Ottoman Commissioner, telegraphed yesterday to the native press officially contradicting the rumour of the plague having broken out at Djeddah, where the public health he states, is very satisfactory.
Alexandrian Nationalists

"Al Lewa" comments on a letter signed "The Nationalists of Alexandria” which it has received expressing the intention of the party to actively support Mohamed Ferid Bey, a Cairo advocate, in his prayer to H.H. the Khedive to grant Egypt a Constitution.
The Khedive's Railway

The Khedive’s Railway The narrow guague line has reached Al Dabba, and the broad guage Al Omayed, 45 kilometres from Sidi Abderahman, the terminus, 145 kilometres from Alexandria. A force of the Khedivial guard are watching the line. When this line is completed his Highness intends to build one to Siwa Oasis.
The Assyr Mutiny

Our Port Said contemporary, the "Verite,” announces that the Otttoman Commissary has asked for a steamer to send back the mutineers to Beyroot, and that this ship is hourly expected. The Suez Canal Company refuses to allow the Assyr through, as she has explosives on board. She is moored out of the way, and is watched by coast guards and marines from H.M S. Venus.
British Soldier Assaulted

A Cairo contemporary reports that a British private was assaulted on Friday evening in Madhi street, and severely wounded on the head, by an Italian sop-keeper. The soldier had stumbled on a mat which the shop keeper had left in the street, and on the private blaming him for his carelessness, the Italian savagely assaulted him. He is now in custody.
The Alhambra Theatre

The performance billed for this evening at the Alhambra theatre is the Geisha, and we are glad to note that it will be the occasion of Signors Baldi's benefit. Signorina Baldi has contributed in no small degree to the success of this delightful musical comedy, and though we have found occasion to criticize to a certain extent her impersonation of "Mimosa San,” chiefly on account of her far too slow rendering of her songs in general, and the "Goldfish" song in particular, we can assure those of our readers who have not seen her in the role of the leading Geisha of the tea-house that her general presentation of the part is excellent. Our best wishes for a “bumper” house.
New Employment Registry

The British Chamber of Commerce gives notice that it has commenced an employment register, which may be consulted by members requiring clerical or other assistance. Applications will be received, free of charge, from clerks and others wishing to obtain posts in Egypt. Address, Secretary, British Chamber of Commerce, Alexandria [Advt.]

div.head: The Labban Death
div.p: Doctors Disagree>

The following report concerning the death of Osman Ahwed subsequent to alleged ill treatment at the hands of policemen of the habban caracol was supplied to us this morning by the authorities of the Alexandria Government. In consequence of the death, which occurred on the 21st inst. at the Labban police station, of a native youth, against whom an aggression on the part of policemen is alleged, a postmortem examination was held by the police medical officer, who reported that death was due to natural cause, and that there were no incriminating marks on the deceased's body. The body was subsequently transported to the Government hospital where a second autopsy was held by two doctors attached to the hospital, who reported that death was due to heart disease, but one of the doctors also expressed the opinion that death might have been due to other causes. In consequence of this difference of opinion the body ' was submitted to a third examination by Dr. Betts, director of the Government hospital, who concluded that death was due to heart disease and that the deceased showed signs of having suffered from inflammation of the longs and other internal troubles. Permission for the burial of tho body was then granted by tho Chef du Parquet. We are also informed that, as a result of the statement in our report of Saturday that the man had met his death as the consequence of a severe kick dealt him by an Italian onbashi of police at the Labban oaracol, the Hakem- darieh has written to the Parquet to ask for a report of the result of the official inquiry with a view to determining the responsibility of the policeman. An administrative inquiry into the affair has also been ordered to discover whether the policemen concerned wore guilty of a breach of duty.

div.head: Alexandria Mixed Tribunals
div.p: New Appointements

There is some talk in French Government circles of the impending retirement of M. Bernardi de Sigoyer, judge of the Court of Appeal at the Alexandria Mixed Tribunals, in which event he would be succeeded by Judge Pruners, who has for twenty-one years been the President of the Mixed Courts at Cairo It is stated that Judge Satow will in all probability succeed Judge Archer at the Alexandria Mixed Courts owing to the latter’s retirement to take up his important new Siamese appointment. The appointment of Judge Satow has not as yet been officially announced, and it will not be decided upon until the return of Lord Cromer to Egypt.

div.head: Army Maneuvers
div.p: Relief of Khartoum Garrison

The extensive army maneuvers which are being carried out this summer by the troops of the Army of Occupation certainly exceed in interest and extent those of former years. Next month the North Sudan will be the scene of operations, and our troops will be charged with the relief of the Khartoum, leaving Abbassieh siding by special trains at 8:45 a.m. on the 13th, 17th, 22nd, and 27th October.

div.head: The Late Admiral Chichester
div.p: Rear Admiral Sir Edward Chichester, Superintendent in charge of his Majesty’s naval establishments at Gibraltar, who died last week first saw active service during the Egyptian Campaign of 1882, where, as lieutenant of the Thalia, he won a war service promotion as commander, together with the more barren honours of the "Crippy” medal and the Khedive’s Bronze Star. In 1884-85, for the Nile Expedition to Gordon's relief, it was Chichester who was selected as principal transport officer, and his exertions gained for him the special thanks of the Admiralty for the perfect organization that had contributed so materially to tho celerity with which the expeditionary force and its mass of incubus had been landed.

div.head: Steamer Movements
div.p: The Messageries Maritimes mailboat YangTse, which left Marseilles last Thursday, passed through the Straits of Messina on Saturday, and is due at Alexandria early tomorrow morning.

div.head: Company Meetings
div.p: Egyptian Land & General Trust
Increasing Values Reported

The annual general meeting of the Egyptian Land and General Trust, Ltd., was held on the 1st inst. at Winchester house. Old Broadstreet, E. C., Sir William F. Haynes Smith, K.C.M.G.,LLD. (tho chairman of the company) presiding. The Secretary having read the notice convening the meeting, The Chairman said: Gentlemen,—I do not desire to detain you with any lengthened observations. The report and accounts place tho position of the company plainly before you. Since the 30th of June the investments grouped under the beading "Other Investments," £13,462 16s. 1d., have been realised at a small profit and the amount applied in reduction of the outstanding amounts due for the purchase of land, which has been reduced by £15,778 5. 3d. The capital of the company has been invested in building lands at Cairo, at Alexandria, and at Khartoum,and in each case the lands have risen in value since they were purchased. We wore advised that it was undesirable to realise these properties within the period of the accounts now laid before you; but we are proceeding with the steps necessary for the realisation of these properties to the best ad- vantage. The Ghorbal Estate at Alexandria is an exceptional property, and, as I have already mentioned, it appeared, expedient, in the interests of the shareholders, to refuse an offer for it, which would have yielded a profit of over £30,000. It would have been pleasant to have been able to give to the shareholders a large dividend on the first year of working, but it seemed expedient, after having taken the risk of purchasing this property, that the share- holders should reap the full profit to be derived from its proper development Its position as being almost the only remaining building area in Alexandria, a vast commercial centre, which is daily growing in importance, appears to render this property independent of the ordinary fluctuations which may affect the land market in Egypt. We also for similar reasons declined an offer for another property, which would have yielded a profit of about £7,O0O. After receiving the best advice we can obtain, the Board believe that these properties will yield larger profits than those offered, and they are taking action for the purpose.
New Business

During the negotiations which have been pending, many matters have remained in abeyance which are being proceeded with. Offers of new business on terms which appear to be favourable are now being dealt with by the Board, and there is no reason to doubt that the operations of the company can be made a success for the shareholders. I now beg formally to move the adoption of the report and accounts. Mr. J. Woodrow Matthews seconded the motion. The Chairman invited questions, but none were asked and he thereupon put the motion for the adoption of the report and accounts, which was carried unanimously. The Chairman next moved the confirmation of the appointment of Mr. E. Toriel as a director, which was seconded by Mr. A. P. Mack, and agreed to. On the proposition of Mr. C. H. Rigg, seconded by Mr. Veasey, Messrs. Annan Kirby Dexter and Co. were reappointed auditors of the company. In acknowledging a vote of thanks, the Chair- man said the duty which he had had to perform at that meeting had not been very arduous, and he hoped that if he had the pleasure of meeting the shareholders in future similar unanimity would be shown. The proceedings then terminated.

div.head: The Khedive's Yacht
div.p: An interesting insurance was effected at Lloyd’s last week on the Khedive's pleasure yacht Mahroussa. This vessel, now valued at £100,000, has, as we recently reported, been entirely reconstructed, having been fitted on the Clyde with three of the most modern steam turbines and otherwise converted from a paddle into a screw steamer. The previous Thursday she succeessfully ran her official trial trip in the Firth of Clyde and attained a speed over a measured distance of 17.75 knots. The present insurance covers the yacht against all maritime perils on her voyage out to Alexandria, via Gibraltar and Constantinople, at which latter port it is anticipated that the Khedive will go on board. Until the vessel is officially delivered she is in the hands of the contractors, who have provided in the insurance contract that the yacht will be navigated as far as Gibraltar in the charge of a special pilot. Seeing that the Mabroussa was originally built of iron on the Thames as long ago as 1865, some underwriters have been surprised that she was worth the enormous amount spent upon her reconstruction, but they are unanimous in considering her a first-class risk for the voyage out, as she is practically an entirely new yacht, inferior probably to no other pleasure craft of the same type afloat. The Mabroussa is not the first yacht built for a distinguished potentate which has been insured in London. Some time ago after the Sultan of Turkey’s new yacht was constructed on the Tyne, she was insured for her maiden voyage to the Mediterranean for £80,000.

div.head: Alexandria-Marseilles
div.p: A 75 Hours' Passage.

The Egyptian Mail Steamship Company Limited is pushing on the construction of its fleet for its service between Marseilles and Alexandria, and the first of its turkine steamers will be ready to be launched next May. Lady Cromer has been asked to christen the first steamer and to preside at the ceremony of launching, which will take place next summer. The service between Marseilles and Alexandria will begin to run from the 15th October, 1907. The steamers are being built Fairfield's. The time occupied by these turbine steamers in the passage between Marseilles and Alexandria will not exceed seventy five hours. The steamers after leaving Marseilles will call at Tania, and this will be the only port of call on the journey. It is expected that the passenger service between Marseilles and Tunis will be a lucrative asset of the Company, as now there is no first class line of passenger steamers plying between Franco and Tunis. The Egyptian Mail Steamship Company will be under contract with the Egyptian Government to carry the mails from London to Cairo in one hundred hours. The present mail service by way of Brindisi and Port Said frequently exceeds this limit oven when there are no untoward circumstances in transit. A special train in connection with the steamers will be run by the Internationstional Sleeping Car Company from Calais by Paris to Marseilles. At Paris these express trains will connect with part of the trains from Belgium, Germany, and the north. The steamers will fly the Egyptian flag.

div.head: Cape-Cairo Railway.
div.p: Rich Copper Deposits

Rich new deposits of copper have been found in the north of Rhodesis, and as a result of the discovery it has been decided to proceed at once with another extension of the Cape to- Cairo railway. The line, which has reached Broken Hill, is now to be carried a hundred miles further north, to Bwana N’Kubwa, in the vicinity of which there is said to be great mineral wealth. This extension will take the railway close to the Congo State border, and it is believed that in a few years it will be continued to the southern shores of Lake Tanganyika. The extension will also facilitate the linking up of the Rhodesian lines with the new railway,which is to traverse the Congo State from Lobita Bay.

div.head: American Transport's Voyage
div.p: (From our Suez Correspondent.)
Suez, Sunday

The U.S. transport Glacier, which, it will be remembered, escorted the American floating dock Admiral Dewey to Manilla last April, has returned to Suez and entered the canal yesterday afternoon, after a successful voyage.

div.head: The Cotton Market
div.p: In their weekly report upon the cotton market Messrs. Collinge Brothers remark that tho chief feature this week has been the bureau report of Monday giving the condition on the 25th ulto. as 77.3 against 82.9 last month. This was a lower figure than had been anticipated in general and in conjunction with the deterioration news which had been received after the 25th ulto, caused considerable covering by "shorts." There has, however, been but little real "bull” support and we are against the market for the long ran in view of the facts that the South has been offering more freely lately, crop news again reads favorably in general and that an increased crop movement may shortly be expected.

div.head: Bulletin de la Bourse
div.p: (Aujourd’hui a midi et demie.)

Notre marché se trouve déprimé du fait de la hausse du taux privé d'escompte a 4 1/2 % et de l'incertitude des places européeunes. Cette situation se traduit par one baisse presque générale de la cote, sans qu'il y ait en, d’ailleurs, beaucoup d’affaires traitées. Les valeurs qui ont été surtout échangées sont comme précédemment la National Bank, la Cassa di Sconto, les Nungovich Hotels, la Delta Land, et le Comptoir. La National perd 3/16 á 26 3/8, les Nungovich 3/16 á 17 1/8, la Delta Land 1/16 á 3 9/32, ainsi que la Land Back á 8 15/16 Let autres pertes sont peu importantes. L'obligation Crédit Foncier Egyptien gagne 3 francs á 338. Un fléchissement plus accentué aurait probablement pour effet d'attirer des acheteurs.

div.head: Supplement Commercial et Financier. DE “L'EGYPTIAN GAZETTE”
div.p: Le Supplément Commercial et Financial l’ "Egyptian Gazette” paralt chaque Samedi midi, de facon á pouvoir etre expédié par le paquebot sutrichien. Il contient des revues complétes et impartisles du coton, des graines de coton, et du marché des valeurs; les derniéres statistiques jusqu á la veille de sa publication: des tableanx des fluctuations de la place et les copies dos dépeches officielles | envoyées á la Liverpool Cotton Association, etc etc L'abonnement pour une année en Egypte coute 1 L.E. y compris les frais de poste; poor l’étranger 10 P.T. deport en sus.

div.head: Fashionable Weddings
div.p: Captain Charlton- Miss Whitaker

The marriage took place at St Peter's, Eaton-square, on Saturday the 15th inst., of Captain Claud G. Charlton, Assistant Military Secretary to the Sirdar, and Miss Gwendoline Whitaker, daughter of Mr. Arthur Whitaker, of Chiddingstone Hall, Edenbridge, Kent. The Rev. Prebendary Storrs, Vicar of St. Peter’s, assisted by Canon Brooke, took the service. The bride, who was given away by her father, wore a gown of white lace and chiffon with white satin Court train, tulle veil, and wreath of orange blossoms and myrtle. She was attended by nine bridesmaids—Miss Dorothy Whitaker (sister), Miss B. M. Whitaker, Miss Phyllis Agnew, Miss Joy Agnew, Miss D'Erves Allen, Miss Violet Edwards, Miss Victoria Wingate, Mias Madeline Rory, and Miss Naville Harter. Masters Raymond and Geoffrey Whitaker (brothers of the bride) acted as train-bearers. Mr. Sacherwell Coke, Irish Guards, was best man. The presents were numerous, and included from the Queen of Spain, silver salt-cellars; Princess Henry of Battenberg, silver cigarette lighter and ash tray; the Sirdar and Lady Wingate, silver sauce-boat; Mr. Arthur Whitaker, diamond tiara; Mrs. Arthur Whitaker, diamond ring; Sir Rudolf Von Slatin, silver cake-basket; and the household servants at Chiddingstone Hall, a large silver tea-tray.
Captain Reeves- Miss Allen

At all Saints’ Church, Cockley Cley, on the 4th inst., the marriage took place of Captain H. C. Reeves, RA, son of the late Col. H. N. Reeves, Bombay Staff Corps, and Mrs. Reeves, Palace-gardens-terrace, Kensington, and Miss Elsie M. Allen, yougest daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Francis Allen, of Ramleh, Egypt, and Cockley Cley HalL. Swaffham, Norfolk. The service was conducted by the Rev. D. E. Nicholas, the Rev. A. M. Harbord, and the Rev. E. Harris, rector of the parish, and the church was decorated with quantities of flowers, ferns, and palms. The bride, who was given away by her father, wore a lovely gown of ivory satin with sleeves, yoke, and a flounce of Limerick lace, the gift of her mother, with sprays of orange blossom and white heather. Her veil of embroidered tulle was arranged over a wreath of orange blossom, and her ornaments included a diamond crescent and bow brooch, and an aquamarine and pearl pendant. She carried a shower bouquet of white flowers, the gift of the bridegroom. The bridesmaids were Miss Ursula and Miss Gwen Allen (sisters of the bride), Miss Lilian and Miss Violet Reeves (sisters of the bride- groom), Miss Olive Auley, and Miss Eileen Chataway. Master Chris Briscoe acted as page, and wore a white cloth Louis XV. costume braided with gold. The bridesmaids wore ivory soft satin dresses, with gold tissue belts and bows and white crinoline hats trimmed with tulle feathers and pink roses, and carried shower bouquets of pink roses and amilax. The bridegroom’s gifts to them were pearl crescent brooches, and the bride’s to the little page was a pearl grenade scarf pin. The best man was Major Henvey, R.F.A. After the ceremony a reception was held at Cockley Cley Hall by Mr. and Mrs. Francis Allen, and Captain and Mrs. H.C. Reeves left later for Norwich. The bride’s going-away gown was of pale blue cloth trimmed with white silk braid, and a lace yoke and sleeves and she wore a toque of white crinoline. The presents were many and beautiful.

div.head: Personal and Social
div.p: On Saturday Prince Mohamed Aly visited the tomb of the late Sayid Abdul Khalik El-Sadat, situated at the foot of the Mokattam Hills, where he was received by Sheikh El-Balm, son-in-law of the late Sayid El-Sadat, who was a sincere friend of his Highness.
Sir Reginald Wingate is expected to arrive in Cairo on the 6th prox. on his return from England.
Mustapha Pasha Fahmy is on his way to the exhibition at Milan. He will stay in Italy till the 17th Ocotober,returning here on the 21st.
Ibrahim Pasha Neguib, under secretary of State for Foreign Affairs, left yesterday for Cairo,
Lord Edward Cecil returns here from Cairo tomorrow evening.
Maltre Carton de Wiart is leaving Cairo for London about middle of next month for a shot visit.

Mr. and Mrs. George Royle and their ai daughter, Mrs. Maclean, wife of Colonel C. W Maclean, commanding the 16th Battalion, Egyptian Infantry, have returned to De Vere Gardens, Kensington, and are due to arrive in to Egypt on November, by the P. & 0. S.S. Caledonia.
Sharif Pasha, Turkish Minister at Stockholm, arrived here this morning on his way to Cairo. His brother-in law of Abbas Halim Pasha.
Shawl Bey, translator of the Khedive, returned here yesterday from Stamboul, whither he bad gone on a private mission.
Dr. Kawoski Bey, physician to H. H. the Khedive, has arrived at Alexandria on his return from Alexandria, where he accompanied his highness.

div.head: The Advance of Egypt
div.p: Financial Activity

M. de Reffye, French Consul at Cairo, in an interesting article to “L’lnformation" on the economic situation in Egypt, remarks upon the financial activity in Egypt during the year 1905-6, when quite a number of companies came into being in Cairo, and furnished the occasion for the introduction of a large amount of foreign capital. He divides the companies into land, financial, industrial, commercial, transport and hotel companies. There are other two branches not included in this list—namely, land mortgage, in which French capital plays the moat important role, and those companies with registered offices abroad—principally in London, Paris and Belgium, which are governed by their respesctive national laws, and which he has failed to find out much about. It is difficult to determine what is the proportion of capital subscribed by foreigners and natives respectively in those companies which have been issued in Egypt, for the foreign element amongst their shareholders is resident in the land, and cannot be easily sorted out. Eleven land companies were founded in 1905 and three in 1906, with a capital of 113,500,000f., and the contribution of the Egyptians thereto, always admitting the uncertainty named above, was about 84,500,000f. France shared to the extent of about 4,500,000f, whilst French- men in Egypt contributed about 780,000f. Other races took part as follows:—English, 7,070,000f; Anglo Egyptians, 15,700,000f; Belgians, 11,276,00f; and Dutch 2,000,000f, Two financial companies were established, whose combined capital was 17,500,000f, which was taken up in Egypt There was but one "industrial," a cigarette company, in 1905, with 625,000 fr. capital, of which Germany subscribed 325,000f, England 125,000f, and the balance was made up by Germans in Egypt or by pure Egyptians; but in 1906 there have been five such companies, with a combined capital of 4,500,000f, almost entirely locally subscribed by English and Belgians, except for 550,000f, subscribed by Austrians. There were six commercial companies with relatively small capital, subscribed to almost entirely by the English and French in Egypt. There have been likewise six transport companies, with about 4,130,000f capital The total companies established were five, with a combined capital of 8,590,OOOf, to which Egyptians, French Egyptians, Syrians and English were large contributors. The disposition is strong, he sums up, on the part of the foreigner to support land companies, and particularly so in the case of the French.

div.head: Sport and Play
div.p: Khedivial Yacht Club
The following are the results of the race on rating of Saturday

The wind was fresh from the N.W., and a very pretty start was witnessed, nearly all the boats being over the line within a few seconds after the starting gun was fired. The largest boats soon drew away from the smaller, until it became a following race.
The following are the results the race on rating which was held yesterday:

Yesterday only five boats turned up. The “Calypso” did not race on account of her old sails, which are quite worn out. The "Minnie" leaked so badly in the first race that it was not worth her while starting on the second one. The Isis II. very pluckily started in both races, and continued to the end of each.

Above are given both the actual finish and the corrected times according to the allowance made for rating. It will be seen that the Anake was first in each case; she therefore wins the cup. The Sans Pareille was very unlucky in each race; in the first one she made a bad start, and in the second one when halfway round the first round she carried away her jib, which split right up, being apparently very old. This was most unfortunate as she was fighting well with the Ananke for first place. The Fen Follet did not come up to what was expected of her, being beaten by the Ananke in the first race by approximately 4 1/2 minutes and in the second by approximately 8 1/2 minutes; her sail does not appear to be as well stretched as it might be. The Banshee did very well in the second race in comparison with the only other local built boat, viz Fen-Follet, only being beaten by her by 1 min. 26 secs,which difference no doubt is due to her being the older boat.

Owing to an error in last Wednesday’s report of the results of the races the Fen-Follet was omitted. She also had the misfortune of dropping part of her crew overboard, but they we repicked successfully and no damage done.

div.head: Commercial & Financial Supplement of the "Egyptian Gazette."
div.p: Commercial & Financial Supplement OF THE “Egyptian Cazette."

The Commercial and Financial Supplement of the "Egyptian Gazette" is published at midday every Saturday in time for the Austrian Lloyd's mail. The supplement contains exhaustive and important reviews of the cotton, cotton seed,and stock and share markets, with all the latest statistics up to the evening of the preceding day, complete tabular forms of the various market fluctuations, and the copies of the official telegrams of the Liverpool Cotton Association, etc., etc. Subscription for one year P.T. 100 (inclusive of postage in Egypt. For abroad the postage is P.T. 10 extra). For further particulars apply to the Manager “Egyptian Gazette."

(Voie). La nomenclature des dits articles ainsi que les conditions de la vente se trouvent aux Magasins Généraux do Boulac cil on peut eu prendre connaissance, chaque jour, de neuf heures du matin hune heure p.m., sauf les dimanches et jours fériés.

Pour être admis à concourir, le soumissionnaire devra verser, au préalable, L.E. 10 (dix Livres Egyptienne)à titre de dépôt provisoire. Le soumissionnaire déclaré adjudicataire devra parfaire cette somme jusqu'à concurrence do 10% (dix pour cent) du mon- tant do l’oftre agréée, et enlèvera à ses frais les lots qui loi seront adjugés dans on délai de trente jours à compter de la date de l'avis d’acceptation de son offre, les dimanches et jours fériés non compris.
Toute offre faite ou déposée postérieurement au jour et à l’heure ci-dessus ne sera pas prise eu considération.
L'Administration ne s’engage pas à accepter les prix les plus élevés ni n'importe quelle offre. Elle se réserve le droit de diviser 1* vente.
Le Caire, le 22 Septembre 1906. 28553-2-1

div.head: ANGLO GERMAN BITTERNESS. INSIGNIFICANT YACHTING INCIDENT GERMAN GOVERNMENT SATISFIED
div.p: London, September 22.
A fresh outburst of Anglo-German bitterness has arisen out of an insignificant incident.
The tourist yacht Meteor attempted to moor at a Government buoy in Portsmouth harbour and was requested to move to the merchant anchorage.

Distorted versions of the incident have been published in Germany alleging that the captain of the Meteor was insulted and compelled to put to sea in a storm. This has resulted in the publication of articles offensive to England.
The German Government has asked the Embassy to report on the facts of the Meteor incident, but has made no representations to the British Government. (Reuter)
LONDON, September 22.
It is understood that Germany is satisfied with the result of the enquiries regarding the Meteor incident. (Reuter)

div.head: CUBANS IRRECONCILABLE. INTERVENTION IMMINENT.
div.p: Washington, September 22.
The feeling it growing here that the differences between the Government and the insurgents in Cuba are irreconcilable and that intervention is likely to take place at any moment. (Reuter)
Havana, September 23.
1,500 Americans are preparing to land to defend the city in the event of the collapse of the negotiations. The situation is somewhat improved. (Reuter)

div.head: THE NEW CRETAN COMMISSIONER. DISCUSSION ENDS IN A FIGHT.
div.p: Athens. September 22.
The Powers agree to the nomination by the King of M. Zaimis as Cretan Commissioner.(Havas)
Athens, September 23. M. Zaimis has been appointed High Commissioner of Crete in succession to Prince George. (Reuter)
Canea. September 23. A discussion regarding international control which took place in the Chambor resulted in a fight. International troops were called and cleared the Chamber. (Reuter)

div.head: BLACK VERSUS WHITE. NEGRO TROUBLES IN GEORGIA.
div.p: New York, September 23. Negro assaults on white persons in Atlanta (Georgia) have resulted in a general attack on negroes, 55 of whom are reported to have been killed or injured. (Reuter)

div.head: DUTCH EAST INDIES. REBELS' ISLAND CAPTURED.
div.p: THE HAGUE, September 22. The Dutch troops have captured Badoeng, the stronghold of two rebel Princes in Bali Island. The Princes with their retainers and women and children, to the number of 400, perished in the last desperate sortie. Four white soldiers were killed on the Dutch side, and 10 wounded. (Reuter)

div.head: TYPHOON IN THE PHILIPPINES. CAVITE ARSBNAL DAMAGED.
div.p: A typhoon struck the Philippines to day. The arsenal at Cavite and the shipping were damaged. (Reuter)

div.head: THE HONG-KONG TYPHOON. SERIOUS COST TO UNDERWRITERS.
div.p: London, September 22. It is estimated that the Hong Kong typhoon will cost London underwriters upwards of a million sterling. (Reuter)

div.head: THE SULTAN'S ILLNESS SUFFERING FROM CANCER.
div.p: The “Temps” affirms that the Sultan is suffering from cancer of the kidneys, which proves fatal within a year. (Havas)

div.head: HOME RACING
div.p: LONDON, September 22. Prince Edward Handicap. (Manchester) 1. Aurina; 2. Polymers; 3. General Kuroki. (Reuter)

div.head: THE PETERHOF PLOT. NOT DIRECTED AGAINST THE TSAR.
div.p: Vienna, September 22. The Peterhof plot was not laid against the Tsar but against the Grand Dukes Vladimir and Nicholas. Three Palace servants have been arrested. (Havas)
St. Petersburg, September 22 Numerous arrests have been made in connection with the Peterhof plot. Searchlights from the Palace sweep the harbour and sea coast. (Reuter)

div.head: BOMB THROWN AT GOVERNOR SOLLOHUB.
div.p: Riga, September 23 A bomb was thrown at the Governor, General Sollohub, whilst he was walking in the street here. He escaped uninjured. (Reuter)

div.head: THE ODESSA RIOTS.
div.p: Order is maintained with difficulty here. 15 persons were killed or wounded yesterday owing to a collision between the police and the mob. (Reuter)

div.head: THE GRANTHAM DISASTER
div.p: London, September 22. The Great Northern Railway experts who are investigating the Grantham disaster are unable to explain the cause except by the hypothesis that the driver became ill. (Reuter)

div.head: TOUR OF GERMAN COLONIES.
div.p: Berlin, September 22 Herr Dernburg, the new Colonial Secretary, proposes making a year's tour in order to visit the German colonies after the opening of the Reichstag. (Reuter)

div.head: AMERICAN MISSION TO CONGO.
div.p: Washington, September 22 President Roosevelt has sent a Consul to the Congo to report on the exact situation. (Reuter)

div.head: FRENCH EPISCOPAL LETTER.
div.p: PARIS, September 23. The French episcopal letter upon the Separation has been read in all the churches without incident. (Havas)

div.head: THE MONGOLIA REFLOATED
div.p: HONOLULU, September 22 The Mongolia has been refloated. (Reuter)

div.head: FRANCE AND TURKEY THE DJANET OASES
div.p: The semi-official announcement that on August 21 an Iradé was published recognising French claims to the ownership of Djanet, an oasis or group of oases on the borders of Tripoli and the Algerian Sahara, marks, it may be hoped, the conclusion of a dispute which has for some time past engaged the serious attention of the French and Turkish Governments. The precise position of the frontier has still to be determined, but now that the main question has been settled the rest is more or less a matter of detail. The incident, though small perhaps in itself, is important as a type of the alarms which must be expected to recur so long as tho frontiers of Tripoli remain undefined. The Anglo-French declaration of March, 1809, is constantly cited in connection with this question, and it is an important document in the case. But in the interests of historical and geographical accuracy it appears desirable to point out that Tripoli is not so much as mentioned in tho Declaration, and it is a little difficult to understand the semi-offioial announcement in which, with reference to the rumours regarding the proposed occupation of Djanet in the name of the Sultan, it is stated that "the Freneh r Government was unable to permit this an- Government was unable to permit this encroachment into the interior of a region which never belonged to Turkey, and which was recognized as French territory by the Anglo-French Agreement of March 21, 1899”
Anglo-French Declaration of 1899

The Anglo-French Declaration signed at London on the 21st of March, 1899, happily put the finishing touches to the amicable solution of the Fashoda quetsion. It completed the Convention concluded between France and Great Britain in the previous year, respecting the delimjtation of their possessions and spheres of influence in West Africa, by defining, in principle, a line of frontier to the north of the Congo State. The British Government engaged not to acquire either territory or political influence to the west of the line, while the Government of the French Republic entered into a similar engagement respecting the acquisition of territory or political influence to the east of the line. The frontier followed the Congo-Nile watershed as far as the 11th parallel of north latitude, and thence followed as far as tho l5th parallel the frontier between the Kingdom of Wadsi and what constituted in 1882 the Province of Darfur. The third provision of the Declaration states that "it is understood, in principle, that to the north of the 15th parallel the French zone shall be limited to the north east and east by a line which shall start from the point of intersection of the Tropic of Cancer with the 16th degree of longitude east of Greenwich." From this point the frontier was to run first south- east and then south till it met the frontier of Darfur.
The Sultan's Claims

To understand the situation thus created it is necessary to remember that the Sultan of Turkey maintained a claim to the indefinite extension of the Tripoli southward in the direction of Lake Chad. This claim had never been regarded at all seriously, and certainly was not supported by effective occupation of the Saharan oases, bat its definite rejection by both France and Great Britain, whose new frontier split the Sahara to the south of Tripoli in two, was not allowed to pass without protest on the part of the Sultan, who refused to recognise the Declaration. Some apprehension was also excited in Italy, for the position with regard to Tripoli is rather remarkable. No attempt has been made on the part of Italy to disguise her ambitions in that direction, and official statements which have been made on the subject on more than one occasion since the Anglo French Declaration of 1899 have made it clear that an understanding has been reached by Italy with both France and Great Britain to the effect that in the event of any disturbance of the status quo neither of the latter Powers will place any obstacle in the way of Italian aspirations. Satisfied with this understanding, Italy presumably has acquiesced in the Declaration of 1899. France has been particularly active during the last few years in extending her influence in the Sahara and establishing securely her position in the sphere of influence marked out for her, and the prospect of any recognition by either the British or the French Government of the Sultan‘s claims with regard to the extent of the Tripoli hinterland is more remote than ever.
Position of Djanet

But the important point to remember in connection with the dispute over the Djanet oases in that the frontier defined in the 1899 Declaration did not extend further north than the Tropic of Cancer, whereas Djanet, as marked in M. Paul Pelet's French Colonial Atlas, published in 1901, lies well to the north of that line. Last year it was stated in the Journal of the Paris Geographical Society that the oases lie between the 24th and 9Sth parallels of north latitude, so that it does not seem possible to sustain the assertion that the occupation of the oases by Turkish troops would constitute an encroachment on the French zone as defined in 1899. It does not necessarily follow, how ever, that the Sultan has any substantial claim to Djanet. There can be no doubt that the proposed expeditionary force had for its object the assertion of those larger claims respecting the extent of the Tripoli hinterland, which France will never admit. In this connection it is noteworthy that Djanet is situated about ninety miles to the south west of Ghat, for, according to the limits assigned to Tripoli by Western cartographers, not only is Ghat a frontier town, but beyond Ghat the frontier runs east and not west.
The Larger Question at Issue.

Comparatively little information is available about the oases. A year last January they were visited by an expedition under Captain Toucbard, an officer of the Algerian Administration, who reported that he could find no traces of Turkish authority. The oases are said to be four in number and to comprise between them from 25,000 to 80,000 palm trees. Between Djanet and Ghat there intervenes the platean region known as the Tassili dee Azdjer, rising to heights of between 4,000ft and 5,000ft., so that it should not be difficult to lay down a boundary which will serve admirably to separate the French from the Turkish possessions at this point. This, perhaps, is all that can be secured at present, but the aim to be kept in view is an agreement between Turkey and France on the one hand and Turkey and Great Britain on the other which shall settle the whole question of the frontiers of Tripoli as regards both Algeria and Egypt. Until this goal is reached there will always be a danger of frontier disputes such as that which has arisen over the Djanet oases.

div.head: LETTER TO THE EDITOR
div.p: We do not hold ourselves responsible for the opinions expressed by our correspondents, but we wish, in the spirit of fair play to all, to permit- within certain necessary limits- free discussion.
A MONROE DOCTRINE FOR AFRICA.

To the editor of the ”Egyptian Gazette” — Sir,- Europe has many tasks to perform in Africa. Firstly, that of pacific penetration those regions of the Continent which are as yet unexplored; secondly, the marking-out of her spheres of political and commercial interest therein; thirdly, the economical development of those spheres. Beside these there are questions which, although more or less subordinate have a place in the ground plan;such, for instance, in Morocco, Abyssinia, the Belgian Congo, and Turkish Tripoli. Gradually those spheres of interest are becoming more and more clearly defined; and acknowledged the consensus of Europe. The reciprocity of the two predominant Powers, Great Britain and France, is vitally necessary to the status quo, commercial and political: for with a huge fleet sweeping its shores ready to co-operate with any military movement on land, danger to the general peace is remote, at present.
Of all questions of internal policy in Africa that of Egypt come first.

To all intents and purposes, it and the Sudan have been absorbed into the British system, with the silent consent of the six Powers; and Great Britain, in return, has, by the support she gave to the Republic at Algeciras, guaranteed France in her Barbary possessions.

Between Great Britain on the East and France on the West is the Ottoman Dependency of Tripoli, occupied by a force which cannot but be antagonistic to European rule; while in te hinterland there is the abstract element of tribal unrest, an unrest which it is naturally in the interest of Turkey to foster. In the far South the Ethiopian movement, no less vague, is of sufficient cause for alarm to Great Britain and Germany. Nor must we overlook the serious complications which may at any moment result from the deadlock in Sinai which ever and anon looms menacingly on the political horizon. So much for the domestic situation. Abroad the external policy of Africa has entered a new phase owing to the claim of intervention set forth by the Kaiser at the time of the Morocco crisis, a claim which has developed i not a demand for a voice in the councils of Europe touching African affairs. In view of Germany’s growing interests and owning as she does, colonies on the East and West coasts of a total area of 843,430 miles, I cannot agree with those politicians who would exclude her from those councils. On the contrary, if ours is a policy of the “Open Door”, we must allow Germany in Egypt as elsewhere the full measure of self-assertion in African affairs, for this is what her so called intervention means; and not only to Germany, but to all other European nations, who have political or commercial relations there.

The not distant goal of common interest can, however, only be attained by a United States of Europe, a Monroe Doctrine of its own. That formula of interstate policy guaranteeing the safety of a vast sub-continent, and holding as good to-day as it did in 1823, when the Powers of Europe attempted to introduce their system of government into South America, is not, I contend, beyond the range of adaptability in Africa. Moreover, there are reasons for urging its adoption, at least in principle, by the Powers of Europe who have vested interests in Africa. The battle of Tsushima shifted the centre of political gravity and opinion in the Far East, and, with the rise of Japan, the awakening of China, and the other races of the Extreme Orient is only natural. With the aid of Japanese nautical skill, the dense population of the Celestial Empire would find immense relief on an African dumping ground, with whose soil some at least of its population are familiar, and it would not be unlikely that the Japanese themselves should aspire to naval supremacy on the Indian Ocean, and seek coaling stations and naval bases on the African littoral. The Japanese are our allies it is true, and as such we are bound to defend thenm, but in a quarrel with a third Power having Colonies on the African coast, such an interpretation of Monroeism would be far more efficaceous than futile appeals to The Hague; the formula would certainly justify in the eyes of Europe the exclusion of any foreign interference in Africa. So, too, coming nearer home, the tenets of the Doctrine might well be applied against the Turkish claim to Egyptian territory at Sinai; or in the case of an insurrection in Arabia which might kindle a highly inflammatory Pan-Islamism in Northern Africa. Take the case also of Tripoli. Surely such a Doctrine might regulate the trade of Italy towards that Province, and hencein check any untoward movement on the part of the Turkish authorities, which might lead to its occupation. There is, besides Morocco, one African Kingdom which needs closely watching. That is Abyssinia. Here again, the African Doctrine would come in very handy for shaping the course of Ethiopian policy, so that it should in no wise affect our interests, commercial and other, vested in the highway from Ospe to Cairo, a railroad which is flanked by this independent kingdom.—
Yours etc Xenos. Bulkeley, September 24.
